stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on a factory level, a remake from a previous project. His main tasks included implementing visual effects like electrical sparkles, fixing a graphical bug with the 'fuzzy' enemy's screen effect, and setting up a special camera for an elevator sequence. The stream highlighted real-time collaboration with his artist Biobak and showcased his pragmatic debugging and problem-solving process.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged a complex positioning bug with sparkle effects by replacing them with Mario models to visualize their path, quickly identifying and fixing a mathematical error in his code.
development_findings.quote: I forgot the SQR, okay now it works. I'm not even gonna test if it works, I just know it works.

development_findings.summary: The team works within the constraints of their tools, accepting that some graphical bugs caused by the underlying graphics plugin (GlideN64) are unfixable.
development_findings.quote: This is unfortunately going to be bugged forever. This is a Glideon bug. Nothing we can do.

development_findings.summary: The current level being developed is a remake of a level from a previous project, 'OnlyBodyMay', with Kaze ensuring that old secrets from the original remain intact.
Future levels are planned, including a 'Space Casino' for Crystal 14 and a 'Paper Craft level' made of cardboard for Crystal 15.
Kaze resolved a camera clipping issue in an elevator not by changing the camera code, but by moving the camera's position and the elevator's collision map, hiding the flaw from the player.
development_findings.quote: So what I'm gonna do is I'm just gonna make it so that the camera is gonna be stuck Further in the elevator... The inaccuracy should not be noticeable.

development_findings.summary: When Kaze couldn't replicate a soft-lock bug related to ledge grabbing, he proactively added safety code to prevent the general condition from occurring.
A dizzying visual and audio effect that occurs when touching a 'Fuzzy' enemy was showcased, which Kaze is particularly proud of.
development_findings.quote: How fucking cool is that effect, dude?

development_findings.summary: A design decision was made to have a radar for secret coins appear only after the player has found three of the five, to guide them without making it too easy from the start.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design philosophy centered on maintaining player agency, expressing intense dislike for games like Super Mario Sunshine that frequently interrupt gameplay with unskippable cutscenes.
context_findings.quote: Every single time the game takes control away from me, it just feels like a small kick to my balls.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is pragmatic about coding standards but expresses significant frustration with external life stressors, specifically ongoing issues with German bureaucracy despite no longer living there.
context_findings.quote: I have accepted that most code is written pretty unoptimized. I just turn into a sad cat when I have to deal with German bureaucracy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes games need to satisfy both intrinsic fun (gameplay) and extrinsic motivation (progress), and feels games like Mario Sunshine fail on both fronts.
context_findings.quote: The intrinsic motivation for me is ruined because all the cutscenes and the extrinsic motivation is ruined because most of it doesn't matter.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels exhausted after working on the game all day, indicating that development is a significant time and energy investment beyond just the streamed hours.

biobak.summary: Biobak created the art assets for the factory level, which Kaze praised as looking 'pretty' and 'amazing'.
Biobak provides real-time artistic feedback in chat, guiding the visual direction of effects Kaze is implementing.
biobak.quote: These are star sparkles, not electrical sparkles.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided crucial technical support by guiding Kaze on how to use the color picker in Blender 4.0 to solve a graphical bug with the 'fuzzy' effect.
Biobak's optimization work, such as removing textures, has resulted in slightly better performance on the N64 for the new level.
Kaze plans to add an easter egg featuring text written by Biobak for a janitor character in the level.

badub.summary: The music for the fuzzy/dizzy effect was highlighted by Kaze as a particularly cool element of the level.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present in the chat at the beginning of the stream and left partway through due to a personal commitment.
Kaze mentions that Bowser's chair animations still need to be implemented, but it is unclear if this is work Zeina has completed or has yet to do.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Sparkle Path
key_stories.summary: When a visual effect for sparkles on a wire failed, Kaze used a clever debugging technique by substituting Mario models to see their path. This allowed him to quickly diagnose and fix a mathematical error in his code, showcasing his efficient problem-solving process.
key_stories.challenge: A sparkle effect intended to travel along wires was spawning incorrectly in a single location, making the effect unusable.
key_stories.process: To visualize the bug, Kaze replaced the invisible sparkle objects with Mario models. This allowed him to see their incorrect movement path, which led him to inspect the positioning code and find the mathematical error.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze identified the missing square root function in his distance calculation. His confidence in the fix was so high he knew it would work without testing, and the sparkles then correctly followed the path.
key_stories.key_quote: I forgot the SQR, okay now it works. I'm not even gonna test if it works, I just know it works.

key_stories.title: The Fuzzy Effect's Unwanted Rim
key_stories.summary: A graphical glitch was ruining a key visual effect. The programmer, Kaze, was stuck due to an update in their 3D software. He collaborated live on stream with the artist, Biobak, who guided him to the solution, demonstrating their effective real-time teamwork.
key_stories.challenge: A screen-distorting 'fuzzy' effect had a graphical glitch causing an ugly, immersion-breaking rim around the screen.
key_stories.process: Kaze knew he needed a specific color value from the 3D model but was stymied by a new version of Blender. He asked his artist, Biobak, for help in the stream chat. Biobak guided Kaze through the new UI to find the correct color picker tool.
key_stories.outcome: With Biobak's guidance, Kaze successfully used the new tool in Blender to get the correct color value and apply it as a primitive color in the game's code, fixing the bug and making the effect seamless.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh, that is exactly what I needed.

key_stories.title: The Elevator Camera Hack
key_stories.summary: To fix a camera clipping through a wall, Kaze devised a clever workaround. He moved both the camera and the invisible floor the player stands on, effectively hiding the graphical issue without a complicated code change, showcasing his pragmatic problem-solving.
key_stories.challenge: A special fixed camera inside an elevator was clipping through the environment when the player jumped, which looked unprofessional.
key_stories.process: Instead of trying to create complex camera code, Kaze opted for a simpler, practical solution. He moved the camera's fixed position further inside the elevator and then moved the elevator's invisible collision floor to match, hiding the clipping from view.
key_stories.outcome: The practical fix solved the visual clipping issue without requiring complex code changes, demonstrating a pragmatic approach to development where an elegant 'hack' is preferred over a time-consuming 'proper' fix.
key_stories.key_quote: The inaccuracy should not be noticeable and this should keep the player from getting themselves into a pickle.
